Situation1: The partner received disappointing feedback at work and is visibly upset.
Situation2: A life-support device in the intensive care unit is flashing critical fault codes.
Story:
My phone buzzed just as I was about to leave for the hospital. It was Mia, her voice trembling. She’d just gotten some harsh feedback from her boss, and I could hear the tears she was trying to hold back. “Can you come over? I just need you,” she whispered. My heart twisted—I wanted nothing more than to be there, to hold her and tell her she was more than her job.

But then my work phone rang. The hospital’s ICU—one of the life-support machines was down, flashing critical errors. I was the only technician on call. The nurse’s voice was urgent: “We need you now. Someone’s life depends on it.”

I stood frozen, phone in each hand, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in. Mia needed me to be her anchor, to listen and comfort her. The hospital needed me to be precise, focused, and fast. I could feel the panic rising, torn between the person I love and the responsibility I can’t ignore. My mind raced, heart pounding, as I tried to figure out who needed me more in this impossible moment.
